summary: This is a Daily Mail newspaper article from July 3, 2020, reporting on the arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell by the FBI in New Hampshire. It details the charges against her for allegedly grooming and trafficking underage girls for Jeffrey Epstein, mentions the renewed call for Prince Andrew to cooperate with US investigators, and summarizes the indictment's allegations against Maxwell. This is a Daily Mail news article from July 3, 2020, detailing the arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell at her secluded New Hampshire property named 'Tuckedaway'. The article covers her life in hiding, her connections to Jeffrey Epstein and Prince Andrew, reactions from victims and their lawyers, and her background as the daughter of Robert Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Arrested at her secluded New Hampshire property 'Tuckedaway'; accused of being at the center of Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring; long-time associate and ex-girlfriend of Epstein; close friend of Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Disgraced financier and Maxwell's former boyfriend, described as having a sexual preference for underage girls. He is the central figure for whom Maxwell allegedly groomed victims. He died by suicide in August 2019.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Former friend of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. US prosecutors publicly urge him to 'talk to us' and give a statement regarding the investigation. He denies allegations of having underage sex with an Epstein accuser.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Acting US Attorney for the Southern District of New York who held a press conference detailing the charges against Maxwell and calling for Prince Andrew's cooperation.

persons.name: William Sweeney
persons.context: FBI official who commented on Maxwell's arrest, stating she had 'slithered away' to a property in New Hampshire and lived a life of privilege.

persons.name: Andrea Johnstone
persons.context: Judge who presided over Maxwell's initial court appearance via video link in Concord, New Hampshire, reading her rights and remanding her to custody.

persons.name: Robert Maxwell
persons.context: Disgraced father of Ghislaine Maxwell; died in 1991 after his yacht accident; his financial crimes forced Ghislaine to relocate to New York.

persons.name: Richard Kay
persons.context: Author of the article's headline and likely a contributor.

persons.name: Sam Greenhill
persons.context: Chief reporter credited with writing the main body of the article.

persons.name: Daniel Bates
persons.context: Co-author of the article.

persons.name: Rebecca English
persons.context: Co-author of the article.

persons.name: Bill Sweeney
persons.context: FBI official who commented on Maxwell's arrest, stating they had been discreetly keeping tabs on her whereabouts.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Lawyer acting for alleged victims, including Virginia Giuffre; commented on Maxwell's arrest and the pursuit of Epstein's co-conspirators.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: One of Epstein's victims; alleges she was trafficked by Maxwell and had sex with Prince Andrew three times when she was 17.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: Represents 16 of Epstein's victims; commented on Maxwell's arrest and the hope for accountability.

persons.name: Lisa Bloom
persons.context: Represents five Epstein victims; applauded Maxwell's arrest and called for others to be brought to justice.

persons.name: Spencer Kuvin
persons.context: Represents six Epstein victims; expressed happiness about the arrest but caution due to past failures in prosecution.

persons.name: The Queen
persons.context: Expressed concern and anger over the Maxwell arrest and its implications for her son, Prince Andrew, and the Royal Family.

persons.name: Prince Philip
persons.context: Mentioned as being in lockdown with the Queen at Windsor when news of Maxwell's arrest broke.

persons.name: Prince Charles
persons.context: Mentioned as brokering the action to strip Prince Andrew of royal duties.

persons.name: Prince William
persons.context: Mentioned as brokering the action to strip Prince Andrew of royal duties.

persons.name: Duchess of York
persons.context: Expressed concern about Maxwell's influence on Prince Andrew and his reputation; introduced Andrew to Maxwell.

persons.name: Princess Beatrice
persons.context: Maxwell was a guest at her lavish 18th birthday costume ball in 2006.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as appearing in photographs with Epstein and Maxwell at Mar-a-Lago.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Allegedly implicated in Epstein's crimes; appears in pictures with Maxwell and teenage girls on Epstein's private island.

persons.name: Vicky Ward
persons.context: Wrote a 2003 Vanity Fair article where Epstein called Maxwell his 'best friend' and noted strange gatherings.

persons.name: Heidi Klum
persons.context: Threw a 'pimps and prostitutes' theme party which Prince Andrew and Maxwell attended.

persons.name: Ralph Lauren
persons.context: Prince Andrew and Maxwell appeared at a Ralph Lauren launch in New York.

connections.description: Described as former boyfriend and girlfriend who conspired to recruit, groom, and sexually abuse underage girls together. Maxwell allegedly managed Epstein's properties.
Described as former friends. Maxwell's arrest leads to public calls for Andrew to cooperate with investigators.
Implied association through Maxwell. An unnamed accuser alleges she was forced to have underage sex with Andrew by Epstein.
Maxwell allegedly groomed the 14-year-old victim for group sex with Epstein, taking her on trips and being present during abuse.
Maxwell allegedly flew the underage victim to Epstein's ranch, gave her an unsolicited massage, and encouraged her to massage Epstein.
Maxwell allegedly groomed and befriended the teenager in London, arranging interactions with Epstein and encouraging her to massage him.
Giuffre alleges Maxwell recruited her as a teenager for Epstein's sex trafficking ring and was present during abuse.
Father-daughter relationship; his death and financial crimes led to her relocation to New York.
The Duchess introduced Prince Andrew to Maxwell and later expressed concern about Maxwell's influence on him.
Both allegedly implicated in Epstein's crimes; pictured together with teenage girls on Epstein's island.
Boies is a lawyer representing Giuffre and other Epstein victims.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: FBI conducts a dawn raid and arrests Ghislaine Maxwell at her hideaway in New Hampshire.

events.title: Press Conference Announcing Charges
events.description: Acting US Attorney Audrey Strauss holds a live-streamed press conference detailing the indictment against Maxwell and calling for Prince Andrew's cooperation.

events.title: Initial Court Appearance
events.description: Maxwell appears via video link before Magistrate Judge Andrea Johnstone in Concord, New Hampshire. She is read her rights and remanded to custody to be sent to New York.

events.title: Alleged Grooming and Abuse Period
events.description: The period during which Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with Epstein to groom and sexually abuse multiple underage girls in New York, Florida, New Mexico, and London.

events.title: Maxwell's Depositions
events.description: Maxwell gave sworn, out-of-court testimony (depositions) in 2016 where she denied knowledge of Epstein's scheme, sex toys, or giving massages, which now form the basis of perjury charges.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself in jail after being charged with multiple sex crimes.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein struck a deal with officials, admitting to soliciting a minor for prostitution and receiving 18 months in jail.

events.title: Infamous Photograph Taken
events.description: Photo taken at Maxwell's Belgravia home of Prince Andrew with his arm around the midriff of then 17-year-old Virginia Giuffre.

events.title: Death of Robert Maxwell
events.description: Robert Maxwell drowned after falling from his yacht, leading to the exposure of his financial crimes.

events.title: Victim Reactions to Arrest
events.description: Multiple victims and their lawyers publicly react to Maxwell's arrest, calling it a step towards justice.

locations: New Hampshire (location of Maxwell's arrest and hideaway)
Ranch in New Mexico (Epstein's property near Santa Fe)
London (Maxwell's personal residence and location of alleged abuse)
Concord, New Hampshire (location of initial court appearance)
Southern District of New York (jurisdiction where charges were filed)
Epstein's private island in the Caribbean
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested by the FBI on July 2, 2020, on charges related to the sex trafficking and abuse of minors for Jeffrey Epstein.

The indictment alleges Maxwell groomed at least three underage girls (as young as 14) between 1994 and 1997, taking them to Epstein's properties in New York, Florida, New Mexico, and her own London home.
US prosecutors publicly urged Prince Andrew to cooperate with their investigation following Maxwell's arrest, stating their 'doors remain open' for his statement.
Maxwell is charged with multiple counts including conspiracy, enticement, transportation of minors, and two counts of perjury related to her 2016 depositions.
Prosecutors revealed Maxwell had substantial financial resources, including 15 bank accounts with around $20 million, making her a flight risk.
Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on July 2, 2020, at a secluded $1 million property named 'Tuckedaway' in Bradford, New Hampshire, which she purchased anonymously through a limited liability company.

The FBI stated Maxwell had been 'discreetly keeping tabs on' and had traveled internationally at least 15 times in the three years prior to her arrest, with about 15 bank accounts holding up to Â£18 million.
Maxwell is described by victims and prosecutors as the 'centre' of Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring, accused of recruiting underage girls and participating in abuse.
The article details Maxwell's close social ties to Prince Andrew, including her role in introducing him to Epstein, and her presence at royal events like Princess Beatrice's 18th birthday party.
Multiple victims' lawyers, including David Boies, Gloria Allred, and Lisa Bloom, welcomed the arrest but emphasized the need to pursue other co-conspirators.
